objtitle.title: *God Writing Upon the Tables of the Covenant*

objinfo.medium: pencil, pen and ink, and water color

provenance.name: National Gallery of Scotland
provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts no later than c. 1805; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; possibly the work offered at Sotheby's, 26 June 1852, lot 182x, not titled (11s. to "Butts," probably indicating that the work did not sell and was returned to the vendor, Thomas Butts, Jr.); Foster & Son auction, London, 29 June 1853, lot 116, titled "The Ten Commandments" (£1.10s. to the dealer Henry G. Bohn); acquired at an unknown time by William Findlay Watson; bequeathed by Watson in 1881 to the National Gallery of Scotland.

desc.objtitle: God Writing Upon the Tables of the Covenant, Object 1 (Butlin 448)

objnote.p: Blake signed the work, lower right, with his monogram; see the textual transcription. The verso is inscribed, lower right, "D 2281," not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The subject of this design, God writing on the tablets of the Ten Commandments, is briefly described in both Exodus 31:18 and Deuteronomy 9:10. In the center of the design stands God, facing away. He wears a transparent gown, through which His muscular physique is clearly visible. He has long, white hair that appears to be blowing to the left, as though by a wind. His left leg is bent backward slightly and on tiptoe. His arms are raised between the vertical and 135 degrees, with His left palm vertical and His right hand pointing upward. He has just begun to write on the tablets, as the single letter near the top of the right tablet indicates. Below God, a figure kneels and bends forward in a bow. This is most likely Moses. He wears a gown and his left foot is visible beneath the hem of his gown. He faces away. Twenty-three figures hover in the flames around the left and right sides of the design. These may be angels, even though they have no wings. The bottom right group of figures contains at least five figures. The leftmost figure is a male with flame-like hair. He appears to wear a gown and faces to the right and slightly forward. The figure second from the right appears to be a male with cloth draped around his waist. He faces away, with his body twisted slightly so he looks right and down. His right foot is visible. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees and he holds a long horn in his right hand, which he presumably blows into. The central figure appears to be a nude female with her hair in a bun. She faces away and is visible from the shoulders up. Her right arm is raised vertically and bent over her head. The figure second from the right appears to be a female(?) and may be gowned. She faces right and looks down. The rightmost figure is a male(?) with short, curly hair. He faces forward and down, as well as to the right slightly. He may be partly clothed in a draping cloth. His right arm is raised horizontally (relative to his body) and he holds a long horn in his right hand. The horn is to his mouth and he presumably blows into it. The central group of figures on the right side of the design consists of five figures. The leftmost figure is a nude, muscular male with short, curly hair. He faces right and down, as though his body is horizontal or he is bending forward. His right arm is raised horizontally and his left arm is bent upward over his head, as though he is supporting the bottom right corner of the tablets that God is writing on. The figure above and second from the left is of indeterminable gender, but faces right and may be gowned. The central and lowest figure may be male and nude. He faces away, with his long hair blowing (by a wind?) to the right, and looks slightly left. The figure second from the right appears to be a female with long hair. She may wear a gown. She faces forward and to the right and is bending forward slightly. The figure above and to the right has short, curly hair and may be nude. It faces away and is of indeterminable gender. The topmost group of figures on the right side of the design appears to be a pair. The leftmost figure is only visible from the neck upward and is of indeterminable gender. It faces to the right and down and has curly hair. The rightmost figure is gowned, but of indeterminable gender. It faces down and to the right, but turns its head to face away. The topmost group of figures on the left side of the design appears to be a pair, both gowned and facing left and up. Both figures may have long hair, though their gender is indeterminable. The central group of figures on the left side of the design consists of four figures. The top figure is a male with short, curly hair. He may wear a gown. He faces right and up. The figure second from the top may be a female with her hair pulled back. She may wear a cloth draped over one shoulder. She faces away and to the left. Her left arm is bent upward over her head. The bottommost figure in the group is a male with curly hair. He faces to the left and his body is horizontal. He may have a strap of cloth over his right shoulder. The rightmost figure of this group is a nude male with short, curly hair. His body is horizontal and he faces left. His left arm is bent upward over his head and he holds onto the left tablet with his left hand. He may be supporting the weight of the tablet on his back. The bottom left group of figures in the design contains five figures. The topmost figure may be a male with short, curly hair; he looks to the right. The figure second from the top may be a male with curly hair. He faces left and down, with a horn to his lips. His left arm is raised horizontally and his left hand holds the long horn. The central figure may be a gowned female(?) with curly hair that is short or pulled back; she faces left and down. The figure second from the bottom may be a partly gowned male(?) with long hair. He faces left and bends forward to look down. His right arm is raised horizontally (relative to his body) and he holds a long horn to his lips with his right hand. The bottommost figure may be a female with curly hair and a headband. She may be gowned, though her shoulders are bare. She faces down and to the left, with both arms raised horizontally (relative to her body) and both hands holding a long horn to her lips. God stands in front of a pair of stone tablets, onto which He has just begun to write the commandments. On the top center of the right tablet is a Hebrew letter. God stands on a stone that may represent the top of Mount Sinai. Flames and smoke radiate outward from the center of the design. A fiery sky may be visible in a break in the smoke and flames at the top center of the design.

lg.l: לThis Hebrew letter (lamed) is inscribed at the top of the stone tablet on the right. This is the first letter (reading right to left) in the sixth commandment, "thou shalt not kill." This commandment usually appears at the top of the left tablet in representations of the decalogue.
